titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jacob Myers scrapbook 1978.109
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-08-25 13:41:20 +0000.

did.abstract: One bound scrapbook compiled by Jacob Myers and containing various news clippings and sample printing work of the Electric Printing Company, such as calling cards, advertisements, tickets, and invoice cards. The volume was originally used as a mailing list for the New York Times. Contents of the scrapbook date from circa 1859 to 1876. Jacob Myers (d. 1901) resided at 1131 Lafayette Avenue in Brooklyn, and was an employee of the New York Times during the 1860s. He was also president of the Electric Printing Company, located at 25 Consilyea Street in Brooklyn

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1978.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Jacob Myers scrapbook, 1978.109, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Jacob Myers (d. 1901) resided at 1131 Lafayette Avenue in Brooklyn, and was an employee of the New York Times during the 1860s. He was also president of the Electric Printing Company, located at 25 Consilyea Street in Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One bound scrapbook compiled by Jacob Myers and containing various news clippings and sample printing work of the Electric Printing Company, such as calling cards, advertisements, tickets, and invoice cards. The volume was originally used as a mailing list for the New York Times. Contents of the scrapbook date from circa 1859 to 1876.
